newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: Lithuanian nuclear plant safety shutdown possible.
newsitem.headline: Lithuanian nuclear plant safety shutdown possible.

text.p: Lithuania's huge Ignalina nuclear power plant could have to be shut temporarily if crucial safety measures were not implemented in time, the country's economy ministry said on Friday.
"It might be that unit one and unit two could be out of operation," economy ministry adviser Jonas Kazlauskas told reporters.
Ignalina's reactors are the largest of the infamous Chernobyl-style RBMK models operating in the former Soviet Union.
Efforts are under way to improve safety during routine maintenance periods after an international safety analysis report this year said extra safety measures needed to be taken.
"These measures exceed 100, but we need to urgently implement six of the safety analysis report measures to start operation of unit one after routine maintenance," Kazlauskas said.
He said the measures include the completion of a draft of emergency procedures and the start of construction of a containment system to prevent the leakage of radiation.
"It's possible that both reactors will not be working for some time if these measures are not implemented," Kazlauskas told Reuters. "But we think this will not be the case."
Kazlauskas did not say when or how long Ignalina could be out of service.
Reactor number one is currently undergoing routine maintenance.

"According to the former schedule, it should start back up on July 1, but we need to implement all six measures," Kazlauskas said. "We think this maintenance could be prolonged for one or two months after July 1."
Reactor number two is expected to undergo routine maintenance after the first reactor is up and running, Kazlauskas said.

The U.S. Department of Energy and Sweden's International Project on Thursday pledged $2 million to help upgrade safety at the plant, which supplies the small Baltic state with 85 percent of its electricity needs.
The plant, which is slated for permanent closure early next century, has been the scene of a number of incidents which have raised concerns about its safety.
The plant was closed briefly last August when a leak was detected in its cooling system. In November 1994, it was shut in response to a bomb threat.
